image.altText: A Caucasian woman with brown hair, wearing glasses and a blazer.

items.synopsis: The next RBA governor is announced after a morning cabinet meeting, following the confirmation that the current governor, Philip Lowe, will not have his term renewed. Follow live.

title.children: 'History-making': PM and treasurer announce Michele Bullock as new RBA governor

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It might be a big day for the central bank, but you wouldn't know it from the outside. My colleague, business reporter Sue Lannin has spent her morning outside the RBA building in Martin Place in Sydney, and says unless you knew what was happening, you'd think it was any ordinary day. Here's what it's been like: "It was busy outside the RBA this morning but not because of the appointment at the first woman to lead the bank. "Members of the Falun Dafa religious group, which is outlawed by China, were protesting. "At one point during my live TV cross they started up with a brass band. "It was pretty quiet apart from that, aside from a few TV camera crews. "Michele Bullock is in Canberra and there was no sign of Philip Lowe."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Business as usual at the RBA offices in Sydney

children.content: It might be a big day for the central bank, but you wouldn't know it from the outside.
My colleague,
business reporter Sue Lannin
has spent her morning outside the RBA building in Martin Place in Sydney, and says unless you knew what was happening, you'd think it was any ordinary day.
Here's what it's been like:
"It was busy outside the RBA this morning but not because of the appointment at the first woman to lead the bank.
"Members of the Falun Dafa religious group, which is outlawed by China, were protesting.
"At one point during my live TV cross they started up with a brass band.
"It was pretty quiet apart from that, aside from a few TV camera crews.
"Michele Bullock is in Canberra and there was no sign of Philip Lowe."

props.alt: A camera on a tripid points at the RBA building.

children.content: Apart from a couple of pigeons, it's fairly quiet near the RBA's headquarters.
(ABC News: Sue Lannin)

props.alt: People standing around in front of buildings in a CBD.

children.content: Other news outlets have been outside the RBA, with Falun Dafa protesters nearby.
(ABC News: Sue Lannin)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Does this mean lower interest rates are on the card ?  - Yohan. Sorry to be the bearer of bad news Yohan, but don't expect this change to result in lower interest rates any time soon. RBA governor Philip Lowe doesn't make the cash rate decision independently — he meets with the broader RBA board to determine what to do with the rate, and Michele Bullock has been sitting in on those meetings in her role as deputy governor ever since rates were increased in May 2022. There's also nothing to suggest that this change in governor will see the bank change its approach. Business editor Ian Verrender explains it better than me — here's what he told David Speers. " What this means to interest rates is  really absolutely nothing. I don't think there has been any criticism of the fact that the Reserve Bank  has actually raised interest rates. "Every Central Bank around the world in every developed nation has raised interest rates, many of them at a  far greater pace than Australia has, and there are reasons why we've  lagged in terms of the rate hikes.  America is up around five, New  Zealand is way above where we are, the UK and the European central  banks both putting through double  hikes just recently. "So these  changes will not affect monetary  policy whatsoever. "I guess from a  positive point of view, we are at or near the peak in interest rates  right now. "We might have one more to go, so, you'd have to say Michele  Bullock will probably not face the kind of public criticism that Philip Lowe has, but she was the deputy  governor during this whole period  and she has presided with Philip Lowe over these interest rate hikes ."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Don't expect lower interest rates any time soon

children.content: Does this mean lower interest rates are on the card ?
- Yohan
Sorry to be the bearer of bad news Yohan, but don't expect this change to result in lower interest rates any time soon.

RBA governor Philip Lowe doesn't make the cash rate decision independently — he meets with the broader RBA board to determine what to do with the rate, and Michele Bullock has been sitting in on those meetings in her role as deputy governor ever since rates were increased in May 2022.
There's also nothing to suggest that this change in governor will see the bank change its approach.
Business editor Ian Verrender
explains it better than me — here's what he told
David Speers
What this means to interest rates is  really absolutely nothing
. I don't think there has been any criticism of the fact that the Reserve Bank  has actually raised interest rates.
"Every Central Bank around the world in every developed nation has raised interest rates,
many of them at a  far greater pace than Australia

has, and there are reasons why we've  lagged in terms of the rate hikes.  America is up around five, New  Zealand is way above where we are, the UK and the European central  banks both putting through double  hikes just recently.
"So
these  changes will not affect monetary  policy
whatsoever.
"I guess from a  positive point of view, we are at or near the peak in interest rates  right now.
"We might have one more to go, so, you'd have to say
Michele  Bullock will probably not face the kind of public criticism that Philip Lowe has
, but she was the deputy  governor during this whole period  and
she has presided with Philip Lowe over these interest rate hikes

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Was Lowe really paid close to $1 million? Will Bullock get the same? Seems the RBA have brought nothing but misery. - Josh. Hi Josh, thanks for your question. Yes, Philip Lowe was receiving around $1 million in year as RBA governor. The RBA's annual report in 2022 showed Mr Lowe had a base salary of $890,252 a year. He also received $115,171 in superannuation contributions. On top of other benefits, he earned a total of $1,037,709 in the 2021-22 financial year. Given Ms Bullock's wealth of experience, which is very similar to Mr Lowe's, we can expect her to be receiving a similar amount when she takes over in September.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Will Michele Bullock be paid the same as Philip Lowe?

children.content: Was Lowe really paid close to $1 million? Will Bullock get the same? Seems the RBA have brought nothing but misery.
- Josh
Hi Josh, thanks for your question.
Yes, Philip Lowe was receiving around $1 million in year as RBA governor.
The RBA's annual report in 2022 showed Mr Lowe had a
base salary of $890,252 a year
He also received
$115,171 in superannuation contributions.
On top of other benefits, he earned a total of
$1,037,709 in the 2021-22 financial year
Given Ms Bullock's wealth of experience, which is very similar to Mr Lowe's, we can expect her to be receiving a similar amount when she takes over in September.

image.altText: Michele Bullock fronting a Senate estimates hearing

items.synopsis: Michele Bullock will become the first woman to lead the Reserve Bank of Australia, replacing incumbent Philip Lowe following months of speculation about the governor's future.

title.children: Michele Bullock becomes first woman to serve as RBA governor, replacing Philip Lowe

image.altText: A protester holds a sign saying 'sacred land' at a Rio Tinto protest.

items.synopsis: Fair Australia has shared a quote from WA Premier Roger Cook saying the state's new Aboriginal cultural heritage laws and the Voice "do the same thing". But the quote was shared out of context.

title.children: What does the Voice have to do with new laws on Aboriginal cultural heritage in WA?

image.altText: A middle-aged man in a dark suit holds a press conference in front of a lectern. Aboriginal and Australian flags are behind him.

items.synopsis: The pesticides authority CEO and board chair resign, after a review triggered by allegations one of the agency's workers urinated on his colleagues.

title.children: Following claims a public servant urinated on colleagues, pesticides authority CEO and board chair resign

image.altText: Two dolphins, one large and one small, swimming in water.

items.synopsis: As plans progress for a shark-proof enclosure in Perth's south in the wake of a fatal attack, an expert raises concerns they could leave dolphins more vulnerable to collisions with boats.

title.children: Shark barrier plan sparks fears for dolphins in Swan River

image.altText: Dr McCarthy is holding a camera taking a scan of a model ship

title.children: The story of the Batavia is a bloody chapter in maritime history. Now, its wreck has new life

image.altText: hospital_health_halls creek sign

items.synopsis: Nurses in Western Australia's Kimberley region are being pushed to breaking point by staff shortages, violence, and a lack of stable accommodation, according to the state's nurses union.

title.children: Nurses union slams 'third-world' standards in WA's remote hospitals

image.altText: Smiling person, short brown hair, hands on hip, wears Australian Army uniform dress. Sunshine, blurred house, greenery behind.

items.synopsis: When Captain Jesse Noble realised they were gender diverse, it felt like being " hit in the face with a truck". A Christian marriage, their faith, and their career in the army were all at stake.

title.children: How Jesse's dress is overturning the army's gender diversity policy

image.altText: A father holds a baby, as he stands at a window.

items.synopsis: Australian men are reporting high-level loneliness. These experts are trying to understand why, and what can be done to fix the problem.

title.children: Which age group of men are the loneliest? This survey had surprising results

image.altText: Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong speaks during meeting.

items.synopsis: The Australian foreign minister says China needs to continue to free up trade for Australian products if Anthony Albanese is to visit there later this year.

title.children: Penny Wong in frank talks with China over trade and human rights at ASEAN summit

image.altText: Margot Robbie and Ryan Gosling

items.synopsis: The last time Hollywood's actors and writers went on strike at the same time, the biggest stars were fighting for residual pay cheques. Decades later, streaming giants and artificial intelligence are at the heart of the debate.

title.children: 'It's very disturbing to me': Why Hollywood CEOs are outraged actors and writers have walked off the job

image.altText: A graphic illustration of a brain floating in mid air, surrounded by vibrant hues of blue and purple.

items.synopsis: A cheap version of ketamine commonly used as a sedative might help some people with hard-to-treat depression, research finds, raising hopes that the off-label treatment could become less expensive.

title.children: Low-cost ketamine could help people with severe, hard-to-treat depression, study finds

image.altText: A close shot of Philip Lowe wearing a suit against a dark background.

items.synopsis: Reserve Bank of Australia governor Philip Lowe won't be in the top job for much longer, but he hasn't been fired. Here's a quick guide to get you up to speed.

title.children: Why a new RBA governor won't necessarily mean a change to interest rates

image.altText: Peter Dutton rubs his eye.

items.synopsis: The Federal by-election for the seat of Fadden could deliver a blow or a boost for Peter Dutton next week, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: A huge hurdle is coming for Dutton — but a bigger challenge is right behind

image.altText: Two men speak with each other on a cricket field.

items.synopsis: As Ricky Ponting weighs in on David Warner's Ashes future, Ollir Robinson says the "laws are the laws" in regard to Jonny Bairstow's dismissal.

title.children: Ponting backs Warner to score big as Robinson says Aussies had a point in Bairstow dismissal

image.altText: A hand caresses a platypus resting on a blanket.

items.synopsis: The death of a platypus found in a city suburb may reflect the fate of the entire species if we don't pay closer attention to how this Australian animal is faring.

title.children: The platypus survived megafauna and continental drift, but can it survive us?

image.altText: A young woman with grey hair and piercing blue-green eyes looks at her reflection in a handheld mirror

items.synopsis: Meet social media's "greyfluencers" — mostly young women who are encouraging others to embrace the beauty of their natural hair colour.

title.children: 'I haven't looked back': Meet the young women ditching hair dye and going grey

image.altText: A composite image of a woman wearing a blue saree next to a Barbie doll wearing a saree

items.synopsis: Sixty-four years ago, women all around the world couldn't see themselves as Barbie: a stick-thin doll with big-boobs, blonde hair and blue eyes. Three women share whether that's changed for them.

title.children: Barbie went from a stick-thin blonde to saris and nose rings. But has she changed enough?

image.altText: A footballer smiles during training, as her ponytail flies up in the air.

items.synopsis: Australian star Ellie Carpenter says she can't wait to play her Lyon teammates at Docklands tonight, as the Matildas prepare for the Women's World Cup.

title.children: Matildas believe sold-out friendly clash with France is the perfect preparation for Women's World Cup glory

image.altText: Emily Blunt with her arm around Cillian Murphy

items.synopsis: Stars including Cillian Murphy and Emily Blunt leave the event as the SAG-AFTRA strike is announced.

image.altText: Andrew Tate wearing sunglasses walks with brother Tristan

items.synopsis: Andrew Tate, a social media personality known for expressing misogynistic views online, and his brother say the allegations have cost them their freedom and millions in revenue.

title.children: 'Serial liar': Andrew Tate sues woman accusing him of human trafficking

image.altText: On the bottom right corner is a stop sign, two lit up red crosses and police officers walking around in front of a big gate.

items.synopsis: A Secret Service report says a thorough FBI analysis of DNA and surveillance footage failed to find who was responsible for the drugs.

title.children: Investigation into White House cocaine fails to identify suspect

image.altText: A metalic Toyota symbol on a White Toyota Hi-Lux with the defective DPF.

items.synopsis: Toyota has announced a technological breakthrough in batteries, but questions have been raised over the company's dubious EV track record.

title.children: Why some EV drivers are sceptical of Toyota's battery breakthrough

image.altText: A large white space rocket sits on a railway platform, surrounded by forest with some people seen nearby.

title.children: 'A safe and soft landing on lunar surface': India's latest mission to Moon about to blast off

items.synopsis: Elina Svitolina's comeback dream is shattered by another on a similar path as Ons Jabeur once again looks for history and Wimbledon final redemption.

image.altText: A head shot portrait of a male doctor with grey hair and a beard

items.synopsis: With 88 vacancies for doctors across regional Western Australia, the Shire of Dundas faces a difficult task at replacing its only Norseman GP, who closed his clinic this week amid an ongoing dispute with the council.
